channel.title: I wonder
channel.description:
Has anyone of you ever experienced a time when you tried waking up, but it was very hard to do so? Not referring to those normal incidents... it's when you are already conscious, but you find opening your eyes a struggle.
I just did, it's scary shit.

Scary shit when happened to me lol

Happened when I went to Europe I saw some crazy shit

Read full topic

item.title: I wonder
item.dc:creator: @Tom Tom
item.description:
@Tom wrote:

[quote=“Ix Soulcist xI, post:2, topic:366628”]Oh… Yeah.
That has happened to me quite a lot.[/quote]

It happened to me once, It was fucking scary, I’d never had/heard of it before and I couldn’t move. I think I was also having a nightmare before hand so it shit me up even more. Fortunately that was a few months ago, I’ve not had one since.

Read full topic

item.title: I wonder
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

I think I’ve experienced this a couple of times; I never knew what it actually was, but I guess it could be this.

I can kind of open my eyes but am extremely exhausted and can’t really move. Then, I feel some weird sensation in my ears and it actually feels like my feet are levitating off the bed but I’m not able to lift my head up and see for sure – I guess you can attribute it to the “Hypnagogic hallucinations”.

It was pretty weird the first time it happened, but I’ve gotten kind of used to it. It usually happens when I’m severely exhausted and I come home from school and fall asleep on my bed in a face-down position.

Luckily though, I’ve never experienced the panic symptoms described in the article.

Read full topic

item.title: I wonder
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

that mean you woke up and your brain hasn’t told your body to wake up, your brain sort of paralyzing your body when you are sleep, so you won’t repeat the thing you do in your dream, example, walking, or hitting someone, your brain doesn’t want your body sleep walk. when you go to sleep your brain shut most of your body activity down, including mobility, but the only major way it could gather outside info when you are asleep is through your ears (eg, that’s why we use a alarm clock). when you are sleeping your brain is doing a lot of work, its repairing your body.

Read full topic

item.title: I wonder
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

Sleep paralysis

Sleep paralysis is when, during awakening or falling asleep, a person is aware but unable to move or speak. During an episode, one may hear, feel, or see things that are not there. It often results in fear. Episodes generally last less than a couple of minutes. It may occur as a single episode or be recurrent. The condition may occur in those who are otherwise healthy, those with narcolepsy, or may run in families as a result of specific genetic changes. The condition can be triggered by sleep de...

Read full topic
